words.example: Ich habe gegessen. (I have eaten / I ate)
words.example_translation: I have eaten / I ate
words.rule: German perfect tense is used for past actions, like English simple past
words.notes: More common than simple past in spoken German

words.english: How to build the perfect tense
words.example: haben/sein + past participle
words.example_translation: have/be + past participle
words.rule: Perfect tense = auxiliary verb + past participle
words.notes: Two parts: helper verb + main verb form

words.example: Ich habe ein Auto gekauft.
words.example_translation: I have bought a car.
words.rule: Auxiliary verb in position 2, past participle at the end
words.notes: Like separable verbs - participle goes to end

words.example: haben: most verbs, sein: movement/change verbs
words.example_translation: have: most verbs, be: movement/change verbs
words.rule: Haben for most verbs, sein for movement and change of state
words.notes: When in doubt, use haben

words.example: machen → gemacht, spielen → gespielt, kaufen → gekauft
words.example_translation: make → made, play → played, buy → bought
words.rule: Regular verbs: ge- + stem + -t
words.notes: Most predictable pattern in German

words.example: Ich habe gearbeitet. Du hast gekauft. Er hat gespielt.
words.example_translation: I have worked. You have bought. He has played.
words.rule: Most regular verbs use haben + ge-[stem]-t
words.notes: This covers majority of German verbs

words.example: studieren → studiert, telefonieren → telefoniert
words.example_translation: study → studied, telephone → telephoned
words.rule: Verbs ending in -ieren don't get ge- prefix
words.notes: Many foreign/borrowed verbs end in -ieren

words.english: Verbs with be-, er-, ver-, etc.
words.example: besuchen → besucht, erzählen → erzählt, verstehen → verstanden
words.example_translation: visit → visited, tell → told, understand → understood
words.rule: Inseparable prefix verbs don't get ge-
words.notes: Prefixes: be-, er-, ver-, ent-, emp-, ge-, zer-

words.example: trinken → getrunken, singen → gesungen, finden → gefunden
words.example_translation: drink → drunk, sing → sung, find → found
words.rule: Irregular verbs: ge- + changed stem + -en
words.notes: Like English: sing-sang-sung

words.example: essen → gegessen, sehen → gesehen, gehen → gegangen
words.example_translation: eat → eaten, see → seen, go → gone
words.rule: These must be memorized individually
words.notes: Learn these high-frequency verbs first

words.english: Verbs that change stem but take -t
words.example: bringen → gebracht, denken → gedacht, kennen → gekannt
words.example_translation: bring → brought, think → thought, know → known
words.rule: Mixed verbs change stem and take -t ending
words.notes: Small group of verbs with mixed characteristics

words.example: sein → gewesen, haben → gehabt
words.example_translation: be → been, have → had
words.rule: Even auxiliary verbs have past participles
words.notes: Used in complex perfect constructions

words.example: Ich bin gegangen. Er ist gefahren. Wir sind gekommen.
words.example_translation: I have gone. He has driven. We have come.
words.rule: Verbs of movement use sein as auxiliary
words.notes: Think: from point A to point B

words.german: Change of state verbs with sein
words.example: Er ist gestorben. Die Blume ist gewachsen.
words.example_translation: He has died. The flower has grown.
words.rule: Verbs showing change of condition use sein
words.notes: Think: becoming different

words.example: gehen, kommen, fahren, fliegen, laufen, sterben, werden
words.example_translation: go, come, drive, fly, run, die, become
words.rule: Learn these common sein-verbs by heart
words.pattern: These always use sein in perfect tense
words.notes: Memorize this list - very important!

words.english: How to choose the right auxiliary
words.example: Ich habe das Auto gefahren. vs Ich bin nach Berlin gefahren.
words.example_translation: I drove the car. vs I drove to Berlin.
words.rule: Same verb can take haben (with object) or sein (movement)
words.notes: Some verbs can use both auxiliaries!

words.example: aufstehen → aufgestanden, anrufen → angerufen
words.example_translation: get up → gotten up, call → called
words.rule: Separable verbs: prefix + ge + stem + ending
words.notes: Ge- goes between prefix and stem

words.english: Using separable verbs in perfect tense
words.example: Ich bin um 7 Uhr aufgestanden. Er hat seine Mutter angerufen.
words.example_translation: I got up at 7 o'clock. He called his mother.
words.rule: Participle stays together at sentence end
words.notes: Unlike present tense, participle doesn't split

words.example: aufgestanden, angekommen, eingekauft, mitgekommen
words.example_translation: gotten up, arrived, shopped, come along
words.rule: Learn these common separable verb participles
words.notes: Very useful for describing daily activities

words.example: Ich bin angekommen. Wir sind mitgekommen.
words.example_translation: I have arrived. We have come along.
words.rule: Separable movement verbs also use sein
words.notes: Same sein rules apply to separable verbs

day_6.topic: Perfect Tense in Questions and Negation

words.example: Hast du gegessen? Bist du gekommen?
words.example_translation: Have you eaten? Have you come?
words.rule: Auxiliary verb starts the question, participle at end
words.notes: Same question formation as other tenses

words.example: Was hast du gekauft? Wohin bist du gefahren?
words.example_translation: What have you bought? Where have you driven?
words.rule: Question word + auxiliary + subject + participle
words.notes: Standard W-question word order

words.example: Ich habe nicht gegessen. Er ist nicht gekommen.
words.example_translation: I have not eaten. He has not come.
words.rule: 'Nicht' comes before the past participle
words.notes: Nicht goes between auxiliary and participle

words.example: Ich habe nie geraucht. Er ist noch nicht angekommen.
words.example_translation: I have never smoked. He has not arrived yet.
words.rule: 'Nie' (never) and 'noch nicht' (not yet) before participle
words.notes: Useful time expressions with perfect tense

words.example: Ich bin schon in Deutschland gewesen. Hast du schon Sushi gegessen?
words.example_translation: I have already been to Germany. Have you ever eaten sushi?
words.rule: Perfect tense describes experiences up to now
words.notes: 'Schon' (already) and 'schon mal' (ever) are common

words.example: Gestern habe ich eingekauft. Heute Morgen bin ich aufgestanden.
words.example_translation: Yesterday I went shopping. This morning I got up.
words.rule: Perfect tense for recent past events
words.notes: More common than simple past in spoken German

words.example: heute, gestern, letzte Woche, vor einem Jahr
words.example_translation: today, yesterday, last week, a year ago
words.rule: These time expressions commonly appear with perfect tense
words.notes: Learn these together as useful phrases

words.example: Was hast du am Wochenende gemacht? - Ich bin ins Kino gegangen und habe einen Film gesehen.
words.example_translation: What did you do on the weekend? - I went to the cinema and saw a movie.
words.rule: Perfect tense is standard for casual conversation about past
words.notes: This is how Germans actually talk about the past
